title: 4 Simple Methods for Selecting Non-adjacent Cells in Excel

steps.title: Click the first cell you want to select.
steps.content: Click the first cell you want to select. The easiest and most efficient way to select non-adjacent cells or cell ranges in Excel is to use your mouse and keyboard. [1] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Hold down the Ctrl (PC) or ⌘ Cmd (Mac) key.
steps.content: Hold down the Ctrl (PC) or ⌘ Cmd (Mac) key. If you hold the Ctrl key (on Windows) or the Cmd key (on Mac), you can select non-adjacent cells. In contrast, holding down Shift only lets you select a range.

steps.title: Click the other cells you want to select.
steps.content: Click the other cells you want to select. To select additional cells, click each cell while holding down Ctrl or Cmd . To select a range of cells that are not adjacent to the original cell, click and hold on the first cell in the range, then drag to select the rest of the cells. Release the mouse button when you have finished selecting your range. Remember to continue holding down the Ctrl or Cmd key while you click on cells to select them.

steps.title: Release the Ctrl/⌘ Cmd key once you're done.
steps.content: Release the Ctrl / ⌘ Cmd key once you're done. Note that the selection will disappear if you click any other cells while you've got your selection active.

steps.title: Highlight the first cell you want to select with the arrow keys.
steps.content: Highlight the first cell you want to select with the arrow keys. If you want, you can use solely the keyboard to select non-adjacent cells in Excel . [2] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Press the F8 key.
steps.content: Press the F8 key. This will enable "Extend Selection" mode, and you will see it denoted in the status bar at the bottom of the window.

steps.title: Use the arrow keys to select the cells you want selected.
steps.content: Use the arrow keys to select the cells you want selected. If you only want one cell selected, move on to the next step. Otherwise, use the up, down, left, and right arrows to make your selection.

steps.title: Press ⇧ Shift+F8 to stop selecting.
steps.content: Press ⇧ Shift + F8 to stop selecting. The cells you selected will remain selected, and you will notice that you're in "Add or Remove Selection" mode.

steps.title: Use the arrow keys to highlight the next cell you want to select.
steps.content: Use the arrow keys to highlight the next cell you want to select. You can also use the mouse to click the next cell if you prefer, though you can use the arrow keys if you're trying to only use the keyboard.

steps.title: Repeat steps 2 through 4 until you've selected the needed cells.
steps.content: Repeat steps 2 through 4 until you've selected the needed cells. Continue alternating between "Extend Selection" mode and "Add or Remove Selection" mode until you're done.

steps.title: Press F8 again.
steps.content: Press F8 again. This will disable "Extend Selection" mode. Note that the selection will disappear if you click any other cells while you've got your selection active.

steps.title: Click on the blank white box directly to the left of the formula bar.
steps.content: Click on the blank white box directly to the left of the formula bar . This is the Name Box, and typing the name of a cell in this box will highlight it. This method works well if you've got a large sheet with a lot of cells filled in. [3] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Type the cell names or ranges separated by commas.
steps.content: Type the cell names or ranges separated by commas. You could write, for example, A1, C1, E1 to select single cells, or A1:A10, C1:C10, E1:E10 to select a range of cells.

steps.title: Press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Press ↵ Enter . All of the cells you entered in the Name Box will be selected, with the last specified cell being the active cell. Note that if you click any other cells while you've got your selection active, the selection will disappear.

steps.title: Press Ctrl+A (PC) or ⌘ Cmd+A (Mac).
steps.content: Press Ctrl + A (PC) or ⌘ Cmd + A (Mac). To select the worksheet, you can press Ctrl + A on Windows or Cmd + A on Mac. Another way of selecting non-adjacent tiles, especially those that hold specific data, is to use the Find and Replace tool. [4] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Press Ctrl+F/⌘ Cmd+F.
steps.content: Press Ctrl + F / ⌘ Cmd + F . On Windows, press Ctrl + F and on Mac, press Cmd + F . This will open the Find and Replace tool.

steps.title: Enter some data in the "Find what:"
steps.content: Enter some data in the "Find what:" field. For example, if your spreadsheet has a list of names in it and you want to select all the cells with the last name "Johnson" in them, you would enter "Johnson" in the "Find what:" field.

steps.title: Click Find All.
steps.content: Click Find All . All cells containing what you searched for will show up in the Find and Replace window.

steps.title: Press Ctrl+A/⌘ Cmd+A.
steps.content: Press Ctrl + A / ⌘ Cmd + A . To select all of the found cells, you can press Ctrl + A on Windows or Cmd + A on Mac.

steps.title: Close the Find and Replace window.
steps.content: Close the Find and Replace window. All cells containing the info you searched for will be selected. Note that if you click any other cells while you've got your selection active, the selection will disappear.
